messageBody:
Actually, I would argue it's named correctly: the methods tagged
happen before and after whatever the current class defines. On the
one hand, it's an implementation detail, on the other, it's an
implementation detail that is necessarily staring you in the face,
since the annotation must be attached to a method that must be on some
class. In addition, "BeforeClass" could be interpreted as always
meaning "before the whole set of tests being run in this JVM", or
"before each class-level suite", neither of which is true.

Maybe if I tilt my head correctly, I'll see the other definition. Any advice?

David

On Wed, Sep 17, 2008 at 3:45 AM, Steve Freeman <smgfreeman@...> wrote:
> One small point which just struck me is that @Before/AfterClass is
> named after an implementation detail, not the domain. It really ought
> to be @Before/After Suite
